Biting means attention seeking or establishing dominance. My first female 
cat really TERRORISED me, biting, scratching, attacking me, you name it. 
Then I adopted another female kitten, which didn't go well with my first 
cat, but gradually the hierarchy was established: I was the matriarch of 
the pride :) and my authority was unquestioned. Cats need love, as well as 
discipline. Hope this helps :)

top_comment.text:
Ok Jackson, what do I do?  My cat is on a feeding schedule, and has been 
since we got him, but lately (he's now almost 4 years old).  he'll eat and 
be hyper, so I come to play with him, and he won't have anything to do with 
his cat toy, or laser pointer, and if he does, he'll just chase it for 
short distances, and then not show interest (no matter how much I tease him 
with the light or toy).  It's like he's bored with it.  I tried new toys 
and it doesn't seem to make a difference.  When he was 2, he'd jump after 
the toys, and really propel himself high to get it.  now I don't see him do 
that anymore.  What am I doing wrong?  Or is it just old age on his part?  
I never can get him panting either, no matter how hard I try.  Please give 
me some advice.﻿
top_comment.author: Bertminator

comments.text: I don't know about Felicity's cat, but mine is indoor cat only.
comments.author: Bertminator

comments.text:
Don't worry - cats are first children, then teenagers (the first 2 years 
are hell), then they begin adulthood and settle down after they are 3 or 4. 
Yes, they can have kitten already when they are 1 year old, but they are 
still kids, so don't let that fool you (after all, there are plenty of 
teenage pregnancies in the human world...) so back to the point: Your cat 
is growing up. If he is a little bit less active but otherwise healthy, 
it's ok. Once they are 6 or 7 they will want to sleep most of the time 
anyway. If however your cat loses all interest, stops grooming himself, and 
becomes apathetic, of course there is something wrong and you need to take 
him to the vet. If not, don't panic, try new toys, and try to adjust to the 
schedule of when he's in play mood and when he isn't.
One question: Is he a house cat or free range? Because free range cats have 
seasonal activity - in spring they jump to action, and in winter they 
almost hibernate. House cats have the seasonal thing a little less 
pronounced. But my cats, after spending 3 months behind my wood stove 
sleeping, just brought me 3 birds home in 2 weeks. It's spring.
comments.author: Trixinator

comments.text:
Here's a small tip for you, I just witnessed my cat actually jumping at a 
long lost forgotten toy that he loved.  Maybe if you can find one your cat 
will thrive with it also.  I usually tie it up with a good fishing line, as 
the line it comes with is pretty weak, but this is what it looks like 
http://www.officeplayground.com/Assets/ProductPreview/pi2700-2899/2845_magicworm_1b.jpg  
I bought mine at "Dollarama" here in Canada, anid it's only $1.00, and 
comes in 3 or 4 colors.  My kitty loved it today, got him to jump a good 6 
or 7 times.
comments.author: Bertminator

top_comment.text:
My cats have slept when I sleep since they were kittens.  I'm not really 
sure what the heck I did to make this happen, though....Prancer either 
sleeps in a shoe box by the nightstand or by my shoulder and Rafiki sleeps 
at the foot of the bed.  I'm not sure if they stay in those spots all night 
(probably not, knowing cats), but when I wake up they are either still in 
those spots or they've come back to those spots. I say, "Let's go to bed!" 
and they follow me to the bedroom.  When I wake up I say, "Time to wake 
up!" and they follow me to the kitchen.  ﻿

comments.author: Pavlin “Simmol” Angelov

top_comment.text:
Cat's are outside animals, and are not meant to be imprisoned inside! Cats 
that are kept inside are at first agitated and stressed. Eventually they 
lose their spirit.  Something about them dulls out.  Outside/Inside cats 
have a wildness, an aliveness about them, that  prisoners just do not 
have.  I earnestly believe that it is wrong, maybe even animal abuse, to 
keep a cat inside until its wits dull.  Cats need to hunt and explore and 
run.  My cat comes and goes as he pleases, and I can't even imagine keeping 
him locked inside! 

One time I took in a cat that was 'lost' and let him into my home.  After 2 
days with me, I let him outside again, and he came back after a few hours.  
He was with me for several weeks when he started to spray my apartment, so 
that is when I took him to the SPCA (not sure if there is an American 
equivalent, in Canada that is the organization that takes care of domestic 
animals).  And found out that the cat belonged to someone else, and had 
escaped from them.  Sadly, the cat was returned to the original owners, of 
course.

In my view, that cat was lively and vivid and intelligent, and if he 
escaped from his captors (yes I will call them that) and did not return, 
there is a reason for that and they do not deserve to have him.  .  He came 
back to me after 2 days, and always came back after a few hours when I let 
him out. 

I know he is now doomed to a fate of being imprisoned until his wits dull, 
and it saddens me.  If he escapes from his owners the first chance he gets 
and does not come back, he obviously does not want that life with them.

I've been reading in the comments here that some people keep their cat in a 
CAGE??!1? and then wonder why it runs away from them and hides?? Goodness 
gracious! Poor thing!!﻿
top_comment.author: CMO999

comments.text:
+Clete Kass Maybe Nora can't afford to build a caged walkway for her cats. 
Don't be so judgmental.
comments.author: MsAppassionata

comments.text:
Its quite possible to adapt the inside enough that a cat is quite happy 
being only there - though it also requires a lot of commitments ++ from the 
owners. Its more work yes - but it is quite possible. As for the cat you 
found... Male (not castrated) cats often roam around and find new homes... 
regardless of how they are treated in the first one (we had one that 
vanished like that - and yes - that was an indoor/outdoor cat. To this day 
we don't know if he died somehow or found another home++). The fact that 
the actual owners had him tagged and registered actually says a lot 
positive about them - and you've no idea if he ran away or he just decided 
to adopt some more humans. as you've not seen him again, yes there is a 
chance that he's purely an indoor cat now - but there's also a chance that 
he's been castrated and therefore has a far smaller home territory he lives 
in (and consequently is highly unlikely to visit you again for that very 
reason - but is still an indoor/outdoor cat). ... I'd much rather have 
happy homes for cats (even if they live their entire lives inside) than 
having even more cats euthanized because there are no homes for them. (if 
you haven't spayed or neutered yours you should do so pronto - if only to 
ensure that the numbers of cats needing homes don't grow even more.. And 
even more so as it seems to be a male one - cause then you regardless won't 
experience the consequences (or have to consider what to do with the 
kittens)).
comments.author: JunNights

comments.text:
Um mate I could go to UK to Australia and back and still be reading your 
comment
comments.author: Cara the animatronic cat

comments.text:
+flyinspirals Trust me, we've been trying-they responded months after we 
got in touch and want us to trap them ourselves... FERAL CATS! Philadelphia 
is not the best city for getting things done unfortunately.
comments.author: Heidi Shoshana

comments.text:
+Heidi Shoshana That's super kind and lovely of you. But 'constantly 
pregnant' doesn't have to happen! Every city I know of has at least one 
program to catch, neuter, and release strays (back to where they already 
live) so the sad cycle (of feral cats being born wild) doesn't continue. 
It's funded by donations or fees -- you won't have to pay for it. Call your 
local Humane Society or similar organization about this!
comments.author: flyinspirals

comments.text:
+sgdeluxedoc Well said. This whole thread taught me that it really is a 
case by case scenario on whether or not it would be safe for the cat. Every 
owner has every right to do with them as they please, bar abuse. However, 
even for people who can't let their cats out due to safety reasons, I still 
think a cat should get at least a *little* nature time, whether it's in the 
city, the suburbs, or rural. How and when would be up to the owner. That's 
just my opinion though.
comments.author: Clete Kass

comments.text:
Some cats really are indoor cats, and certainly, if you live in tthe city, 
it can be very dangerous to let them outside. I always let mine outside, 
and even did in town, but we were far enough from the road that she would 
be safe from cars. It can be what they get used to, however. You might be 
interested in a YT video called "Tiger in Harlem" where this fella raised 
three tigers in an apartment, and kept one of them for five years.. They 
got along just great, until he took in a stray. Bad choice, as any cat 
person will tell you. He didn't introduce them to each other properly, 
either, so you can guess what happened next. The tiger gave him one jelous 
swipe. Just one, mind you, she showed a lot of restraint. Enough to send 
him for 100 stitches though, and alert the humane society, who, since 
having a tiger in harlem is illegal, took the tiger away .
The point is, although I would never encourage anyone to keep a lion or 
tiger in an apartment, cats, all cats, can adjust to  any living situation 
as long as you provide plenty of care and affection. THat doesn't mean you 
*should* keep them indoors, though. My experience is that cats that have 
large tufts of fur between their toes (paws) realy need to spend some time 
outdoors, whereas those that do not, are completely happy indoors 100% of 
the time. Just my observation, though...
comments.author: sgdeluxedoc

comments.author: Crestina L

comments.text:
+cheryl wallace I know you weren't, dear. (I didnt end up muting this post 
after all lol). I dont judge how people have to raise their cats or dogs, 
different environments call for different scenarios. Disagreements ensue 
because we all want the best for our own, and every owner has the right to 
make those judgment calls. Ive never lived near mountains or farms, so I 
cannot comment on those living situations. I'm lucky I live where the worst 
animal that is possibly out there are racoons, and just like you, I do not 
let mine out too late at night and definitely not when I go to bed. You are 
very kind.
comments.author: Clete Kass

comments.text:
Clete, I hope that you when I agreed with Crestina about that other person 
not having cats; I was not talking about you.
comments.author: cheryl wallace

comments.text:
Crestina, I am so sorry for your cousins loss. We all have to use common 
sense when raising baby animals or/and children. As parents we are to keep 
them safe and if that means keeping them inside then that is what has to 
happen. When you get home put them in a harness and go for a walk each day. 
Yes, I mean put a harness on your cat or kitten and take them for a walk. 
At one time I lived in the French Quarter and had a cat and 2 Shitzus, so I 
bought a leash that was designed to walk more than one furry baby at a 
time. I put the kitten between the dogs who eventually grew taller than the 
dogs, which was cute. They had a wonderful time and I took them for rides 
in the car, too, so they were never deprived of being outside each day, but 
were always safe with me.
As parents of furry babies we always have to take into consideration our 
environment and the babies safety. If they were human children you would 
not just open the door each day and them run free if they were to young. It 
ha a lot to do with common sense.
In the morning my furry babies are fed and I love and play with them, then 
I unlock the pet door and sit outside while they are playing in the 
backyard, because we have coyotes, hawks, etc that would easily carry off a 
kitten, but when my boys were fully grown they were fast and strong. They 
even protected me from a coyote one evening. It approached me with the 
intent to kill with head lowered, ears back and teeth bared. My boys came 
raising out of the house and surround it taking turns swatting at it until 
I could get my bb gun. Once, they saw I was safe they ran back in the house 
and I shot. It did not kill it but bbs really do hurt, so I did not have a 
problem with that one, again. I have wildkife that I have looked after 
since they were babies, especially raccoons and my furry babies arefine 
withem because they would come up on the porch where I was sitting and I 
always have water bowls and food bowls there, too. They would touch me on 
the leg an I would give them some dry food in one of the bowls. They are 
huge, too, now, but still touch me on the leg and I give them food. I named 
them, as well, when they were babies, so I call them and they come running 
on the porch for their last feeding at night.
comments.author: cheryl wallace

comments.text:
So true, Nora, so watch over them and at night bring them inside if you 
live in this kind of environment.
comments.author: cheryl wallace

top_comment.text:
Help! I just bought a 4 months old persian cat yesterday and it was 
vaccinated, and I want to sleep with her on my bed tomorrow night so its 
like 3 days after, but I'm scared if it'll poop or pee on my bed. What 
should I do? This is my first time having a cat. and my mom suggested that 
I should put the litter box in my toilet incase it wants to do business, I 
am really stressed out! :( My mom even told me to let the cat wander around 
the house so it will get used to the environment, but it keeps running to 
closed space and hiding under couches. And I have carpets under the couch, 
and Im really really scared if it'll poop on the carpet or somewhere where 
the cat is hiding. I really need to know when or how many each days will it 
poop? does it poop once a day? Once a night? I know this is really long 
comment, but I have no one else to ask from. Pls help! ><﻿
top_comment.author: angelbrownie1

comments.text:
Cats can have an accident just like people.  They are not perfect and often 
like to puke.  If you cannot deal with any little inconvenience, please do 
not get a pet.
comments.author: Sherry Lee

comments.text:
+angelbrownie1 She sleeps with me year around, but only when she wants to, 
I can't force her to lay in bed with me.  The air condition has nothing to 
do with whether she sleeps with me or not.
comments.author: Whitney A

comments.text: +angelbrownie1~ He doesn't care what is on as long as I cuddle him...
comments.author: grumpy150

comments.text: +Whitney A Do you sleep with your cat when the air condition is on?
comments.author: angelbrownie1

comments.text:
Do not put a cat in a cage.  It will only come to be agitated every time it 
sees you cause it will associate you with being locked up.  A cat needs to 
be allowed to roam, if you don't want him/her in certain rooms, close the 
doors.  Also a cat will use the litter box as long as he knows where they 
are, if he goes somewhere else theres a different problem, could be 
physical mental or just emotional, my cat when she was younger felt she 
wasn't getting enough attention and as soon as I started giving her more 
affection the peeing stopped.  Also a cat will sleep with you but that 
doesn't mean they'll allow you to cuddle them like a stuffed animal. My cat 
sleeps at the foot of my bed and that's her spot.  Occasionally she'll come 
near my head and cuddle with me but it never lasts for to long.  Cats can 
be amazing companions as long as they are given respect and love.
comments.author: Whitney A

comments.text:
+angelbrownie1 Keep it indoor for sure, don't forget his yearly shots, keep 
the litter box clean (fully wash it at least once a week), 3 meals a day, 
wash their meal bow once a day, change water daily, never give sweets, 
chocolate or milk (unless specialized milk for cats) and as it is a 
persian, buy quality food for persians, brush it daily, take to the vet 
every 6 months and for a professional bath at least once every two months 
also so it can has it nails done (don't ever think of declawing the cat, 
that's literally amputation and very painful for the animal), neuter and 
microchip him, buy a couple toys, a scratching post and a bed and you'll 
have a long live wonderful pet.
comments.author: CuteTeef

comments.text:
+angelbrownie1  As long as your feeding your cat regularly you really don't 
have to worry about them running off and not returning. All of my cats have 
the freedom to go outside whenever they please, and three out of my six 
take advantage of that and go out every day. My other three don't feel so 
inclined so they don't go out. My cats usually come back every night but 
often they stay out overnight and occasionally stay out for two or three 
nights, though that is extremely rare. They always return though as this is 
where they have steady food and warmth and family. My cats will let me know 
if they want out by either standing at the door or meowing at the door to 
get my attention and when they want in they will scratch the door to alert 
us. You do, however, need to worry about them being hit by a car if you 
live near a road, though if it's a dead end or a very lite traffic road the 
probability is lower. I live on a country road with little traffic so it 
hasn't been an issue. We've been here for 7 years now and our cats are 
fine, though I do have a fairly decent amount of woods and a creek out back 
so they tend to go that way rather than crossing the street. If you do live 
by a heavily traveled road you may want to keep your cat(s) indoors. Also, 
you mentioned having your cat stolen and this isn't something I have to 
worry about since I know my neighbors but it may be a problem near you, so 
you may want to put a collar on your cat. I don't collar mine but as I've 
said I live in a rather rural region so it works for me. You also have to 
deal with fleas and ticks unless you treat them Monthly, which is what I do 
and have never had a problem with either. I use Revolution flea and tick 
treatment which cost about a hundred dollars for a pack of six and they 
sell it at the vet, but Frontline works well too, as does many other 
brands. We just prefer the Revolution because it's a bit stronger and has 
additional benefits. I advise every pet owner to try and keep up with shots 
too, but if you only have one cat it isn't too expensive. For us and our 6 
cats, food, liter, flea treatment, and shots ends up being a bit pricey, 
but its well worth it.
comments.author: Romeo Volpe

comments.text:
+Karen Smith  My cats pee at least once or twice a day and poop at least 
every other. There are many times they exceed these numbers but this is the 
minimum amount. I've never not had to scoop pee from my liter box and I 
scoop first thing every morning and last thing every night. I used these 
numbers to illustrate the bare minimum  amount to expect. I leave water out 
at all times so they can drink whenever they feel the need. I also leave 
food out at all times, though a few of my cats are slightly over weight so 
this is only recommended if you don't have a cat in need of dieting. I've 
never known any of my 6 cats to poop five times in a single day, that is 
excessive. There bowel movements shouldn't be much different than our own. 
Any vet will tell you that the average for a healthy cat is to poop once a 
day and pee two to four times daily.
comments.author: Romeo Volpe

comments.text:
+angelbrownie1~ My cat is a indoor cat. I don't want him to get hit by a 
car are hurt/killed by another animal. You also have to consider illness 
and fleas your cat can get from being outdoors..
comments.author: grumpy150

comments.text:
+CMO999 I'm just scared that the cat will run off somewhere and gets stolen 
-.- My neighbour had a persian and she let it out. But it never returned.I 
heard persians are house cats aren't they?
comments.author: angelbrownie1

comments.text:
+angelbrownie1
You're right.  I'm sorry, I was reacting emotionally.  The important thing 
to keep in mind is that your cat is a sentient, living, feeling being with 
intelligence and sophistication, and you should respect it as such and not 
keep it confined to a small cage, or even confined to an apartment or 
house.  A cat is fully capable of adapting to its environment, if you only 
let it.
comments.author: CMO999

comments.text:
+Romeo Volpe You gotta be kidding with that, "...cats pee once a day and 
poop every other day"  In my experience, cats POOP as many as FIVE times a 
day, and I can't pretend to know how many times they pee--I'd bet it 
depends on how much they drink!
comments.author: Karen Swim

comments.text:
+angelbrownie1~ Don't stress, cats are very easy to care for and do not 
normally go outside of the litter box... Like Romeo said have a box on 
every level and clean it as often as it's used and she will have no reason 
to go else where.. Also no need for a cage, she is old enough to feed and 
explore on her own... Enjoy her...
comments.author: grumpy150

comments.text: +CMO999 lol its my first time. _
comments.author: angelbrownie1

comments.text:
+angelbrownie1
You should not have a cat.  I'm sorry, but that is the plain truth.  Read 
my comment above and you will see exactly why.
comments.author: CMO999

comments.text:
+Romeo Volpe alright! :) I'll PM you if there is anything I need help with, 
and then again, thank you :)
comments.author: angelbrownie1

comments.text:
You're welcome. I hope you enjoy your kitten. I have 6 cats, all of which 
were rescues that I took in from the street, except one who is was born to 
one of my rescues and I love them all like children. All are fixed, and I 
recommend you fix yours as well, this helps with their behavior as well as 
not getting pregnant. A cat in heat can be really annoying. 3 of my cats 
are indoor/outdoor and 3 are strictly indoor. If you have any further 
questions just let me know!
comments.author: Romeo Volpe

comments.text:
+Romeo Volpe Thank you so much! :) This really helps me a lot! Thanks for 
the tip and the reply! I really appreciate it :)
comments.author: angelbrownie1

comments.text:
As long as you have a litter box that is readily accessible and you scoop 
it regularly the cat will use it and only it. Cats pee once or twice daily 
and poop every other. Also, there is no need for a cage, cats are free 
roaming creatures and need space to enjoy themselves. The cat will most 
likely sleep with you at night so long as the bedroom door stays open, this 
may take a few weeks, but they will surely join you eventually. Cats tend 
to like laying on beds and backs of couches. They also enjoy high places so 
will often try to climb cabinets, washing machines, and refrigerators. They 
are very loving animals but also independent so be patient. Also, to 
discipline a cat, never strike them, this won't teach them anything except 
anger towards you, instead, spray them with water when they misbehave, this 
will teach them to not do what it is that causes the punishment, just make 
sure you spray immediately after they did whatever it is you deem 
punishable. Cats are extremely smart and in my opinion, the best possible 
companions. They will sense your mood and comfort you when yours down. Just 
keep in mind that they are playful and will do things that can annoy you, 
like scratching furniture or interupting your view when reading or on the 
computer, but its out of love. Hope this helped.
comments.author: Romeo Volpe

comments.text:
I showed my cat where the litter box was and when I was sure she new where 
it was she slept with me and she didn't pee or anything x3
comments.author: SkyTheEmolga

top_comment.text:

Thing is, she usually HAS food in her plate and water in her dish - I think

my home!!!!)﻿
top_comment.author: Felicity Mason

comments.text:
In my experience, locking them out just results in crying and serious

comments.author: PraiseDivineMercy

comments.text:
Lock her out of your room! Biting is a no-go area, and she should not have 
the opportunity.
comments.author: Trixinator

comments.text:
I have the same problem with my cat Toby. I have effected some improvement 
in two ways:
1) More play time. I think it lets out the aggression
2) My cats sleep with me. If Toby tries nipping I roll over and give him a 
big hug in a way he does not like. I also put my hand around the scruff of 
his neck like a mother cat disciplines her kittens. Basic idea: always 
respond to the biting by being an annoying PITA in a way that does not harm 
them.

A tiny swat n the nose with your finger will discourage such behaviors. I

comments.text:
+RichieT He has several platforms; he can almost circle the entire living 
room without touching the floor once :) I do plan on getting him a good 
harness and leash and trying to walk him. I just re-read what I typed 
earlier and realized I forgot to mention he is not fixed yet. When he was a 
few months old I noticed he would start breathing really hard after only a 
few minutes of play, and the vet detected a heart murmur. She referred me 
to a cardiologist who diagnosed him with mild cardiomyopathy and we decided 
to hold off on getting him fixed for a little while to see if the murmur 
might close up on it's own, since putting him under anesthesia is risky. 
Yes, as soon as he is fixed though I want to walk him daily, but I am 
concerned that it might not be a great idea while his hormones are revved 
all the time right now. I am hoping that once I get him fixed some of the 
aggressive play might subside too.
comments.author: Jennifer Constantine

comments.text:
+Jennifer Constantine Bengals are not ground dwellers, build some platforms 
and get him off the ground, he'll probably enjoy observing from a higher 
elevation then on the ground.  Your animal may benefit from extended 
walking as well.  Bengals need to roam, about 6 blocks would be about what 
their total area they claim would be, thats alot.  Being couped up would 
drive them batty...
comments.author: RichieT

comments.text:
I cannot clip claws. We started out clipping from the time I brought him 
home at 5 weeks, but after a few months he stopped letting me. It not 
becomes a bloody affair if I try. When  I last took him to the vet for a 
clipping, the vet and her assistant were unable to do it either because he 
fought them so hard.  I do play with him before bed to tire him out, and he 
goes to sleep, but awakens several hours later wanting to stalk my feet 
under the covers. I have tried tucking the sheets in but he is still able 
to borrow underneath. Last night, after I played with him for 45 minutes, 
he had dinner and laid down, but 20 minutes later he attacked my legs 
several times. I tired to ignore it, but as usual I was left bleeding in 
several spots. I know he is playing but it doesn't change the fact that I 
go to work looking like I am a cutter on my arms and legs. I answered and 
ad for free kittens, and later discovered he is a Bengal. High energy. I am 
doing my best, but am exhausted.
comments.author: Jennifer Constantine

comments.text:
you can clip their claws to keep them short, and have play time before bed 
making sure they are exhausted as stated in this video.  Also don't play in

covers, I guarrantee your cat probably learned that bed = play time whehter 
you are in it or not.

comments.text:
Adopt an older cat that is already mellow. When you get a kitten, you don't 
know what you're getting into, and unlike dogs, cats cannot be molded to 
fit your personality as much, they are much more independent. By getting a 
cat that already fits your purrsonality, you're ensuring no problems with a 
rambunctious teenager cat that seems to never sleep.

comments.text: buy a Persian cat they are fuzzy and cute also they chill with you
comments.author: Mikasa Ackerman /Anime Crackhead

comments.text: If you want a laid back cat get the ragdoll
comments.author: Cyrilla Santa-Teresa

comments.text:
+Kelly Zulin I couldn't agree more. One animal in a group always becomes 
the "enforcer". My Maine is that one as well. He's gentle and kind but if 
the other two are going at it he breaks them up and sends each into time 
out until they behave. He's always been a halter cat, outside, to the vet, 
doesn't matter. On car trips he needs to be looking out the window from a 
comfortable perch. We moved recently and my husband had him outside and was 
not paying attention. Go figure he got off the lead and wandered off. My 
husband panicked, I went outside walking around calmly calling for him and 
within a few minutes he was walking up the sidewalk meowing at me as if to 
say "I heard you, quit making a racket" and he calmly walked home with me. 
My husband was floored because none of the other cats would behave that 
way. He acts very much like a dog (even plays fetch with his fuzzy blue 
ball) but so much smarter. It's a breed many people don't know about and 
perhaps pure breads are more difficult. All I know is everyone whose ever 
had one gets sold on these guys and they become owners of multiple Maines. 
He's a water cat and even tho i have an enormous fountain he will only 
drink out of the sink, we have agreed that once we purchase our next home 
the bathroom faucet will be motion sensor so he can do it himself. But if 
he flushes the toilet just to watch the water swirl one more time I may 
have to put a lock on it!! Greatest Cats!
comments.author: beth otoole

comments.text:
+beth otoole I have a taby maine coon mix and he is the coolest, cutest 
thing ever.  He was a stray that I took in and soon became my best buddy.  
He even goes outside with me and stays right by my side like a dog and 
responds to my whistle, now he is also trained on a leash for added 
protection with me by his side.  He later became the sherif when I took in 
another stray, meaning he would look after and groom my new cat, and they 
soon became inseparable.  Maine Coons are almost like dogs, they will 
protect and play with you just as long as they can be close to you.  Go 
cats!
comments.author: Kelly Zulin

comments.text:
I've been lucky enough to have a great cat that is part Maine Coon. He's 15 
lbs of the most NON aggressive, laid back. best cat ever. It still means 
play time but after that it's just hangin' out. I helped raise him as a 
kitten and then he went off to live with my daughter. Fast forward 6 years 
and I have a feisty very territorial feline who was used to living only 
with a dog. Re-enter my beloved Maine Coon who was never aggressive, never 
even lost his temper with her while HE taught HER to talk cat. I have never 
seen another animal take so much abuse. It amazed even me. Now they are the 
best together. She has been caught using him as a pillow. He taught her to 
communicate with him and she taught him to play with her. I am completely 
hooked on the breed. When it comes time for another cat, I'll be looking 
for another Coon. Mine came from a shelter, so keep your eyes open. They 
have pretty distinctive markings, bigger ears, huge paws and really big 
fangs. The only thing he ever bites is his toys,,a really great breed. Oh 
yeah, THE smartest animal I have EVER had. So totally trainable, very very 
smart. Good luck, I hope you find the perfect cat for you,,!
comments.author: beth otoole

comments.text: Thank you! I'll be sure to check them out
comments.author: beardman Smith

comments.text:
I've discovered Maine Coons are generally much more laid back and "chill" 
than more "high-energy" kitties like tabbies. Also, like Niki said - you 
can get a Senior cat - remember healthy, indoor kitties typically live 
18-20 years, so you can really rescue an older cat (even over 7 years old!) 
that's harder to place since most people are looking to adopt younger. PS: 
Allllll cats need play time at least 10 minutes once or twice a day. It 
GREATLY reduces risks for aggressive/problem behavior. Remember, in the 
wild, they bite and scratch to survive, so it's ingrained in their nature. 
It's really healthy for them to get that aggressive energy out on their 
toys, not people or other cats. I know a cat that literally hisses at his 
toy mice while he's playing!!! :)
comments.author: Jackie Eco

comments.text:
Senior cats are good for that. Other than that, maybe a cat statue or 
stuffed animal? You can't expect a cat to just sit there and look pretty 
all the time.

All cats want to play some every day but some are more laid back than 
others. I think your best bet is an adult cat or even approching elderly 
that you already know the activity level and personality of :)

comments.author: TheNellehFox

comments.text:
15 minutes isn't long for a cat.. at all. XDD It's exhausting for a human, 
but not for a cat unfortunately. Try taking a rope or a string (make sure 
to put it away after use) and snake it across the floor. You can do this 
while sitting down, so your cat is the one getting the workout.
If they seem to lose interest, try a different toy, preferable one that you 
know they'd never turn down on a good day. If they aren't interested in 
playing, then you can say you've succeeded. [:

Oh, you're welcome! Just trying to help!

comments.author: Mizuki Kaioh

comments.text:
If you've ever watched "My Cat from Hell," there's an episode where Jackson 
states that a pet owner should play with their cat until the cat is worn 
out. So, when they start panting, you've succeeded... and I'm not sure how 
long this takes will full grown cats, but it takes eons with the babies.
comments.author: xohsodebonairex

top_comment.text:
One of the most important things to remember when dealing with cats is that 
cats, just like people, are individuals.. There ARE some things that fit 
almost all cats (like much of the cat language, both verbal and non-verbal) 
but many things, especially when it comes to habits, can vary widely 
between individual cats..
If you are having trouble schedule-feeding your cats, try free feeding. If 
you've tried free-feeding before and there were some behavioral problems, 
try adjusting how you act instead of how your cats are forced to act. Or, 
try using a better quality food.
Between myself and my wife we have 5 cats (3 at my house and 2 at her 
house) and the only time we've ever had any trouble was when we tried a 
feeding schedule. The feeding worked well, but certain behavioral problems 
(such as scratching furniture and crying at night) started occurring. We 
tried this for a couple of months, but when it was made apparent the cats 
just simply did not like it, we went back to free-feeding and things are 
great.
If your cats are perfectly happy with having food out all the time, sleep 
well enough to let you sleep, and (perhaps most importantly) are able to 
control their eating habits enough to not be overweight, then there is zero 
reason to stop free-feeding.
The advice here on how to free-feed is GREAT, but I felt I should post this 
because some people may not understand that this advice is not applicable 
to ALL cat households.
The only time I've ever had any trouble with free-feeding (that's in a 35+ 
year life with many different cats) has been when times were rough and we 
had to buy cheap cat food. EVERY time I've EVER seen cats put on cheap cat 
food, there have been behavioral issues... If you treat your cat right, 
listen to what they tell you, and STILL have trouble, upgrade the quality 
of their food before trying to alter their lifestyle and habits. I won't go 
into what foods I have found that work or which brands have CONSISTENTLY 
cause problems, because this is not a commercial :)  (I will note that, in 
my experience, the most expensive brands are certainly not always best, 
but, in the same line of reasoning, the absolute cheapest has caused 
problems more times than not)﻿
top_comment.author: Zanaraxtarus

comments.text:
+Zanaraxtarus Thank you for pointing all this out!  Different cats need 
different things.  I've always done the free feeding with about a tbsp of 
wet food for breakfast and dinner.  My last cat would act like she was 
starving to death if we were late with the wet food and would wake us up on 
the weekends for breakfast.  My current cat mostly could care less if she 
gets it or not but she'll direct me to the kitchen if she wants her wet 
food.  Both cats gave up on me going to bed at scheduled times.  Between 11 
and 12 - bedtime for kitty.  They both seemed to like to get up around 4 or 
5, grab a snack, use the litter box and then just hang out on the window 
perch watching the world wake up until I do.
comments.author: Jeandiata Smith

comments.text:
Also, it's important to remember our cats ARE influenced by us in MAJOR 
ways.. As this study:** 
http://www.journalvetbehavior.com/article/S1558-7878%2812%2900122-0/abstract 
** shows, simply living with humans dramatically alters a cat's patterns of 
activity.. This study also shows (although, indirectly) the importance of 
maintaining a set schedule. If you stay up until 2 a.m. a night or two 
every week, you're teaching your cat that staying active that late is 
perfectly acceptable, so of course they don't want to go to bed at 10 p.m. 
through the week, just because you have to work the next day... Consistency 
when attempting to alter a cat's behavior is just as important as 
consistency when attempting to alter a child's behavior.
comments.author: Zanaraxtarus

comments.text:
+tmsouth1 Actually Jackson did an episode of My Cat From Hell with a cat 
that was constantly waking up their owners during the night. He used 
compressed cannister along with a laser trip so that there was a short 
blast of compressed air whenever the cat came up to the bedroom door to 
scratch/meow. It was very effective and it made the cat stay away from the 
door in a harmless way. I think after a couple of weeks they were able to 
remove the compressed air because the cat had learnt not to approach the 
door. It won't make the cat jumpy apart from the sound of compressed air, 
which is naturally mimicking a cats' hiss anyway.

Jackson would never use a training technique that would subject the cat to 
excessive stress or any pain. It is more detrimental to the cat to allow 
them to bother their owner and make them grouchy, impatient and resentful 
towards the cat.

Hi Jackson ,how can i stop free feeding my cat,when i work all day?thank

top_comment.author: christie silva

comments.text:
For cats it's the ritual that counts, not just the food. Just like children 
can take food out of the fridge any time they like, but it's really the 
family meals that are important. So with my cats, I feed them wet food 
twice a day, at 6:30 and 7:00 (and not much, just like 100 grams), and 
during the day they have a bowl of dry food and water if they get peckish. 
But for them it's totally the ritual, because they certainly don't get all 
excited about a little bit of wet food. They want to feel that you are 
taking care of them, and want to have that food out of your hand, and 
preferably, when you eat at the same time. Family meals. Cats are smart.
comments.author: Trixinator

comments.text:

comments.author: Pavlin “Simmol” Angelov

comments.text:
feed them well during morning and evening and maybe a snack during the 
middle of the day, but only after they r 6 months old. Before that, they 
will need to be fed a bit more often. I did this with all my cats. My 
parents did the same with their cats and we never had any problems. They 
will get a bit annoyed at first, but they will get over it in about a week 
or so, when their bodies get adjusted to this new schedule. If you do give 
them 3 meals and snacks in between, they might still wake you up too soon 
because you get their stomachs used to always have to digest something. 
Also, the first meal should be about 1 hour after you wake and the last 
meal should be about 1 -2 hours before going to bed.
comments.author: Cristina Sburlea

comments.text:
we had our kittens on 5 meals a day whem they were weaned and on solid 
food. breakfast lunch and dinner would be a full meal with two 'snacks' in 
between (the snack would be about half of a full meal) . As they grew we 
increased the size of the full meals and just had one snack and eventualy 
no snack between meals. It's on a schedule and they never had problems 
growing up :) our two females had about 4 litters each before they were 
neutered so i do have experience ( the last two litters from our siamese 
even needed the bottle because she is tiny and didn't have enough milk. 
thankfully it was just about 3  bottles a day on top of her breasfeeding 
them and she always asked for help when she noticed that the kittens were 
still hungry after feeding them. Smart little thing. )

comments.author: Clete Kass

top_comment.text:
One question I have, concerns nail trimming.  One cat absolutely refuses to 
allow me to trim his.  He struggles, growls, hisses and even strikes.  I 
don't want to hurt him.  I have cat trees, flat scratch post all over the 
house which he uses.  How so I get him to let me trim those sharp claws??  
NOTE:  The other cats let me.﻿
top_comment.author: T'Mihn Ah'mygahn

comments.text:
Trim one nail, then administer a kitty treat. Then set your cat down and 
walk away. Repeat every 10 minutes. See if that works. You may have to 
administer a kitty treat before hand.

If that doesn't work, you're probably psyching your cat up before hand. In 
that case, change up how you handle nail trimming. Find out where your cat 
is laying, then go to him and clip a nail. Then give him a kitty treat, 
then walk away. Little doses at first so he doesn't get mad, he'll get used 
to it instead. Eventually, you'll work your way up to trimming the entire 
set then giving him a kitty treat. And important, as long as you clip a 
claw, he gets a treat. Don't let his behavior effect if you give him a 
treat or not, he gets one as long as you clip a claw. Clipped claw=treat. 
He'll figure it out eventually.

And always remember, only the tip of the claw!
comments.author: RipleySawzen

comments.text:
if you cant trim your cats nails, try taking it to the vet, or a 
professional groomer. If that costs to much catnip the cat until its 
calmed, and pet the cat, make sure the cat is calm and happy, then try a 
room, that has little stimulation. No bright lights, no sounds. And if that 
doesn't work and the cat still bites, wear a jacket, some oven mitts, cover 
yourself so theres no bare skin, and keep a firm hold, this is what  I do, 
should work :D
comments.author: Flamingjazkinz

captions.text:
Jackson, I haven't
slept in three days.

My cat keeps me
up all night long.
I'm gonna kill her.

No, I'm not gonna kill her,
but Jackson, you gotta tell me.
I'm gonna kill myself here.

Tell me, how do I sleep
through the night?
And I say, oh, that one?
That's easy.

So let me ask you
something, people.
You ready to get cat-ified?
Let's go!

As you have noticed
I'm sure, this
is not exactly the cat cave.
It is a cave.
It's a little echoey in here.

But no, I am in a hotel room
in San Diego, California,

where we are wrapping
up filming the season

of "My Cat from
Hell" season five,

premiering-- coming
up in the spring.

Do stay tuned because
you'll find out

everything you have to know
about the premier of "My Cat

from Hell" here, on
the Cat Daddy channel.
Just, you know, stay tuned.

So today we're
talking about what?

Your cat allowing you to
sleep through the night.

Now, the last
episode I was talking

about the concept of
circadian rhythms,

a cat's 24 hour clock,
and how naturally it

wants to get them
up at dusk and dawn.

We can help guide
their circadian rhythm.
We can reset their body clocks.

But there's a couple of
really important things.

Now when last we met I
also gave you homework,

and that homework
was about making sure

that you established a daily
rhythm, that you establish

rituals that happen
throughout the day that
helps keep their body going.

And the one thing that is
most important to what we're

going to do right now is
they're feeding schedule.

Remember something,
if you allow your cats

to graze all day
long, if you allow

them to eat whenever
they want to eat,

then not only do you not
have a chance of affecting

their behavior
even a little bit,

but you're not
allowing their body

to process food in
the natural way.

They're constantly in
this arc of digestion.

And we don't want that
because then their energy
is totally unpredictable to us.

Here's what I would
ask you to do.
If you free feed, make it stop.

The next step is, you
bring in meal time.

Real big change in a cat's life
is not met with nice things.

And you do not want to
encourage bad behavior,

and by making rapid changes
like that, you kind of are.

We'll keep the dry food
out, but then every day you
just put less and less in there.

And by the end of that first
week that, there is food

down there, they don't feel
like they're missing anything.

But by an hour after
you leave for work,

they've polished it off and
now they're waiting for a meal.
Now here's the rule of thumb.

I would like to see no
longer than between six

and eight hours you
can make it happen.

So you're feeding
three meals a day

and then your cat's
